newsitem.title: GERMANY: German convicted in Austria's Lucona fraud.
newsitem.headline: German convicted in Austria's Lucona fraud.

text.p: A north German court convicted a 62-year-old German of complicity in murder and insurance fraud on Wednesday for his role in the 1977 sinking of an Austrian ship, the Lucona, in the Indian Ocean.

After one of the longest murder trials in German history, the state court in Kiel sentenced Hans Peter Daimler to five years in jail for helping a leading Viennese socialite, Udo Proksch, to sink the ship, which Proksch had chartered as part of a $50 million insurance fraud.
Six crew members were killed in the blast on the Lucona. A Vienna court had already convicted Proksch in 1992 of masterminding the insurance swindle, and sentenced him to life in jail.
Kiel judge Uwe Martensen said the five-year trial had produced sufficient evidence to show that Proksch and Daimler had tried to insure the Lucona as extensively as possible before it was sunk.

The Austrian investigation into Proksch, a former swineherd who owned Vienna's elite Demel coffee house, included a multi-million dollar investigation involving a deep-sea search for the freighter. The investigation concluded it was blown up from inside.
The Lucona affair also prompted the resignation of former Austrian foreign minister Leopold Gratz, who was found guilty of perjury over his role in the affair.
